bibl.title: Letter from W.H. Hoffmann to George A. Kellogg, January 15, 1942

div1.p: Hoffmann requests copies of the portrait, "Conquerors of Yellow Fever," and notes his own work on yellow fever endemic infection.

div1.head: Letter from W.H. Hoffmann to George A. Kellogg, January 15, 1942
div1.opener:
COPY
COPY
COPY
Cerro 1381
Habana, Cuba
Jan 15, 1942
Mr. George Kellogg
John Wyeth and Brother, Inc.
Philadelphia, Penna.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Not long ago I asked the American Medical Association if it is
possible to have 50-100 copies of the picture, “Conquerors of Yellow
Fever” which they had published in the Journal.

They answered, December 9, 1941, that they sent my letter to
your Company and that this Company, after their impression, will be glad
to furnish me with the pictures at no cost.

Owing to absence from Habana I could not follow up the matter
before.

I am working here since nearly 25 years exclusively dedicated to
research work on yellow fever*, and of course am ralated with all the
yellow fever specialists of the whole world. Now I find the picture which
you published very instructive and of great historical interest, and I
should like to send it to my friends together with my own publications on
yellow fever.

I beg to ask if you find it possible to send me 50-100 copies of
the picture and at which price this will be possible.

Through my work on yellow fever and with my own methods I have
been able to discover the endemic infection of West Africa and South America
at a time (between 1925 and 1931) when the universal opinion was that yellow
fever had already disappeared from the world, with the logical consequence
that of course nobody thought of the possibility that yellow fever might be
imported, for instance, (by) every movement to Cuba or to the United States from
the immense but unknown centers which existed at only a few hours distance
(by airplane) in South America.
With my best thanks and compliments,
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, (sgd.) Prof. W H. Hoffmann, M.D.
Director in the Finlay Institute *as Director of the Yellow Fever Department of the Finlay Institute.
